prompt:
What was the name of the last team Pele played professionally?

Edson Arantes do Nascimento (Brazilian Portuguese: [ˈɛdsõ aˈɾɐ̃tʃiz du nasiˈmẽtu]; 23 October 1940 – 29 December 2022), better known by his nickname Pelé (Portuguese pronunciation: [peˈlɛ]), was a Brazilian professional footballer who played as a forward. Widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time, he was among the most successful and popular sports figures of the 20th century. In 1999, he was named Athlete of the Century by the International Olympic Committee and was included in the Time list of the 100 most important people of the 20th century. In 2000, Pelé was voted World Player of the Century by the International Federation of Football History & Statistics (IFFHS) and was one of the two joint winners of the FIFA Player of the Century. His 1,279 goals in 1,363 games, which includes friendlies, is recognised as a Guinness World Record.

Pelé began playing for Santos at age 15 and the Brazil national team at 16. During his international career, he won three FIFA World Cups: 1958, 1962 and 1970, the only player to do so and the youngest player to win a World Cup (17). He was nicknamed O Rei (The King) following the 1958 tournament. Pelé is the joint-top goalscorer for Brazil with 77 goals in 92 games. At the club level, he was Santos's all-time top goalscorer with 643 goals in 659 games. In a golden era for Santos, he led the club to the 1962 and 1963 Copa Libertadores, and to the 1962 and 1963 Intercontinental Cup. Credited with connecting the phrase "The Beautiful Game" with football, Pelé's "electrifying play and penchant for spectacular goals" made him a star around the world, and his teams toured internationally to take full advantage of his popularity. During his playing days, Pelé was for a period the best-paid athlete in the world. After retiring in 1977, Pelé was a worldwide ambassador for football and made many acting and commercial ventures. In 2010, he was named the honorary president of the New York Cosmos.

Averaging almost a goal per game throughout his career, Pelé was adept at striking the ball with either foot in addition to anticipating his opponents' movements on the field. While predominantly a striker, he could also drop deep and take on a playmaking role, providing assists with his vision and passing ability, and he would also use his dribbling skills to go past opponents. In Brazil, he was hailed as a national hero for his accomplishments in football and for his outspoken support of policies that improve the social conditions of the poor. His emergence at the 1958 World Cup, where he became a black global sporting star, was a source of inspiration. Throughout his career and in his retirement, Pelé received numerous individual and team awards for his performance on the field, his record-breaking achievements, and his legacy in the sport.

Early years

Born in Três Corações in Minas Gerais state in Brazil in 1940, Pelé has a street named after him in the city – Rua Edson Arantes do Nascimento. A statue of Pelé is also prominently placed in a plaza near the city's downtown.
Pelé was born Edson Arantes do Nascimento on 23 October 1940 in Três Corações, Minas Gerais, the son of Fluminense footballer Dondinho (born João Ramos do Nascimento) and Celeste Arantes. He was the elder of two siblings, with brother Zoca also playing for Santos, albeit not as successfully. He was named after the American inventor Thomas Edison. His parents decided to remove the "i" and call him "Edson", but there was a typo on his birth certificate, leading many documents to show his name as "Edison", not "Edson", as he was called. He was originally nicknamed "Dico" by his family. He received the nickname "Pelé" during his school days, when, it is claimed, he was given it because of his pronunciation of the name of his favourite player, local Vasco da Gama goalkeeper Bilé, which he misspoke, but the more he complained the more it stuck. In his autobiography released in 2006, Pelé stated he had no idea what the name means, nor did his old friends. Apart from the assertion that the name is derived from that of "Bilé", the word has no meaning in Portuguese.[note 2]

Pelé grew up in poverty in Bauru in the state of São Paulo. He earned extra money by working in tea shops as a servant. Taught to play by his father, he could not afford a proper football and usually played with either a sock stuffed with newspaper and tied with string or a grapefruit. He played for several amateur teams in his youth, including Sete de Setembro, Canto do Rio, São Paulinho, and Ameriquinha. Pelé led Bauru Atlético Clube juniors (coached by Waldemar de Brito) to two São Paulo state youth championships. In his mid-teens, he played for an indoor football team called Radium. Indoor football had just become popular in Bauru when Pelé began playing it. He was part of the first futsal (indoor football) competition in the region. Pelé and his team won the first championship and several others.

According to Pelé, futsal (indoor football) presented difficult challenges: he said it was a lot quicker than football on the grass, and that players were required to think faster because everyone is close to each other in the pitch. Pelé credits futsal for helping him think better on the spot. In addition, futsal allowed him to play with adults when he was about 14 years old. In one of the tournaments he participated in, he was initially considered too young to play, but eventually went on to end up top scorer with 14 or 15 goals. "That gave me a lot of confidence", Pelé said, "I knew then not to be afraid of whatever might come".

Club career
Santos
Main article: Os Santásticos
1956–1962: Early years with Santos and declared a national treasure

Pelé in 1962, by then rated the best player in the world
In 1956, de Brito took Pelé to Santos, an industrial and port city located near São Paulo, to try out for professional club Santos FC, telling the club's directors that the 15-year-old would be "the greatest football player in the world." Pelé impressed Santos coach Lula during his trial at the Estádio Vila Belmiro, and he signed a professional contract with the club in June 1956. Pelé was highly promoted in the local media as a future superstar. He made his senior team debut on 7 September 1956 at the age of 15 against Corinthians de Santo André and had an impressive performance in a 7–1 victory, scoring the first goal in his prolific career during the match.

When the 1957 season started, Pelé was given a starting place in the first team and, at the age of 16, became the top scorer in the league. Ten months after signing professionally, the teenager was called up to the Brazil national team. After the 1958 and the 1962 World Cup, wealthy European clubs, such as Real Madrid, Juventus and Manchester United, tried to sign him in vain. In 1958, Inter Milan even managed to get him a regular contract, but Angelo Moratti was forced to tear the contract up at the request of Santos's chairman following a revolt by Santos's Brazilian fans. Valencia CF also arranged an agreement that would have brought Pelé to the club after the 1958 World Cup, however after his performances at the tournament Santos declined to let the player leave. In 1961 the government of Brazil under President Jânio Quadros declared Pelé an "official national treasure" to prevent him from being transferred out of the country.

Pelé won his first major title with Santos in 1958 as the team won the Campeonato Paulista; he would finish the tournament as the top scorer, with 58 goals, a record that still stands today. A year later, he would help the team earn their first victory in the Torneio Rio-São Paulo with a 3–0 over Vasco da Gama. However, Santos was unable to retain the Paulista title. In 1960, Pelé scored 33 goals to help his team regain the Campeonato Paulista trophy but lost out on the Rio-São Paulo tournament after finishing in 8th place. In the 1960 season, Pelé scored 47 goals and helped Santos regain the Campeonato Paulista. The club went on to win the Taça Brasil that same year, beating Bahia in the finals; Pelé finished as the top scorer of the tournament with nine goals. The victory allowed Santos to participate in the Copa Libertadores, the most prestigious club tournament in the Western hemisphere.

1962–1965: Copa Libertadores success
"I arrived hoping to stop a great man, but I went away convinced I had been undone by someone who was not born on the same planet as the rest of us."

—Benfica goalkeeper Costa Pereira following the loss to Santos in 1962.
Santos's most successful Copa Libertadores season started in 1962; the team was seeded in Group One alongside Cerro Porteño and Deportivo Municipal Bolivia, winning every match of their group but one (a 1–1 away tie versus Cerro). Santos defeated Universidad Católica in the semi-finals and met defending champions Peñarol in the finals. Pelé scored twice in the playoff match to secure the first title for a Brazilian club. Pelé finished as the second top scorer of the competition with four goals. That same year, Santos would successfully defend the Campeonato Paulista (with 37 goals from Pelé) and the Taça Brasil (Pelé scoring four goals in the final series against Botafogo). Santos would also win the 1962 Intercontinental Cup against Benfica. Wearing his number 10 shirt, Pelé produced one of the best performances of his career, scoring a hat-trick in Lisbon as Santos won 5–2.


Pelé with Santos in the Netherlands, October 1962
Pelé states that his most memorable goal was scored at the Estádio Rua Javari on a Campeonato Paulista match against São Paulo rival Clube Atlético Juventus on 2 August 1959. As there is no video footage of this match, Pelé asked that a computer animation be made of this specific goal. In March 1961, Pelé scored the gol de placa (goal worthy of a plaque), against Fluminense at the Maracanã. Pelé received the ball on the edge of his own penalty area, and ran the length of the field, eluding opposition players with feints, before striking the ball beyond the goalkeeper. A plaque was commissioned with a dedication to "the most beautiful goal in the history of the Maracanã".


Pelé before facing Boca Juniors in the second leg of the 1963 Copa Libertadores Finals at La Bombonera.
As the defending champions, Santos qualified automatically to the semi-final stage of the 1963 Copa Libertadores. The balé branco (white ballet), the nickname given to Santos at the time, managed to retain the title after victories over Botafogo and Boca Juniors. Pelé helped Santos overcome a Botafogo team that featured Brazilian greats such as Garrincha and Jairzinho with a last-minute goal in the first leg of the semi-finals which made it 1–1. In the second leg, Pelé scored a hat-trick in the Estádio do Maracanã as Santos won, 0–4, in the second leg. Santos started the final series by winning, 3–2, in the first leg and defeating Boca Juniors 1–2, in La Bombonera. It was a rare feat in official competitions, with another goal from Pelé. Santos became the first Brazilian team to lift the Copa Libertadores in Argentine soil. Pelé finished the tournament with five goals. Santos lost the Campeonato Paulista after finishing in third place but went on to win the Rio-São Paulo tournament after a 0–3 win over Flamengo in the final, with Pelé scoring one goal. Pelé would also help Santos retain the Intercontinental Cup and the Taça Brasil against AC Milan and Bahia respectively.

In the 1964 Copa Libertadores, Santos was beaten in both legs of the semi-finals by Independiente. The club won the Campeonato Paulista, with Pelé netting 34 goals. Santos also shared the Rio-São Paulo title with Botafogo and won the Taça Brasil for the fourth consecutive year. In the 1965 Copa Libertadores, Santos reached the semi-finals and met Peñarol in a rematch of the 1962 final. After two matches, a playoff was needed to break the tie. Unlike 1962, Peñarol came out on top and eliminated Santos 2–1. Pelé would, however, finish as the top scorer of the tournament with eight goals.

1966–1974: O Milésimo and final years with Santos
In 1966, Santos failed to retain the Taça Brasil as Pelé's goals were not enough to prevent a 9–4 defeat by Cruzeiro (led by Tostão) in the final series. The club did, however, win the Campeonato Paulista in 1967, 1968, and 1969. On 19 November 1969, Pelé scored his 1,000th goal in all competitions, in what was a highly anticipated moment in Brazil. The goal dubbed O Milésimo (The Thousandth), occurred in a match against Vasco da Gama, when Pelé scored from a penalty kick, at the Maracanã Stadium.

In 1969, the two factions involved in the Nigerian Civil War agreed to a 48-hour ceasefire so they could watch Pelé play an exhibition game in Lagos. Santos ended up playing to a 2–2 draw with Lagos side Stationary Stores FC and Pelé scored his team's goals. The civil war went on for one more year after this game. During his time at Santos, Pelé played alongside many gifted players, including Zito, Pepe, and Coutinho; the latter partnered him in numerous one-two plays, attacks, and goals. After Pelé's 19th season with Santos, he left Brazilian football. Pelé's 643 goals for Santos were the most goals scored for a single club until it was surpassed by Lionel Messi of Barcelona in December 2020.

New York Cosmos

Pelé signing a football for US president Richard Nixon at the White House in 1973, two years before joining the New York Cosmos
After the 1974 season (his 19th with Santos), Pelé retired from Brazilian club football although he continued to occasionally play for Santos in official competitive matches. A year later, he came out of semi-retirement to sign with the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League (NASL) for the 1975 season. At a chaotic press conference at New York's 21 Club, the Cosmos unveiled Pelé. John O'Reilly, the club's media spokesman, stated, "We had superstars in the United States but nothing at the level of Pelé. Everyone wanted to touch him, shake his hand, get a photo with him." Though well past his prime at this point, Pelé was credited with significantly increasing public awareness and interest of the sport in the US. During his first public appearance in Boston, he was injured by a crowd of fans who had surrounded him and was evacuated on a stretcher.


Pelé entering the field to play his first game with the Cosmos, 15 June 1975
Pelé made his debut for the Cosmos on 15 June 1975 against the Dallas Tornado at Downing Stadium, scoring one goal in a 2–2 draw. Pelé opened the door for many other stars to play in North America. Giorgio Chinaglia followed him to the Cosmos, then Franz Beckenbauer and his former Santos teammate Carlos Alberto. Over the next few years other players came to the league, including Johan Cruyff, Eusébio, Bobby Moore, George Best and Gordon Banks.

In 1975, one week before the Lebanese Civil War, Pelé played a friendly game for the Lebanese club Nejmeh against a team of Lebanese Premier League stars, scoring two goals which were not included in his official tally. On the day of the game, 40,000 spectators were at the stadium from early morning to watch the match.

Pelé led the Cosmos to the 1977 Soccer Bowl, in his third and final season with the club. In June 1977, the Cosmos attracted an NASL record 62,394 fans to Giants Stadium for a 3–0 victory past the Tampa Bay Rowdies with a 37-year-old Pelé scoring a hat-trick. In the first leg of the quarter-finals, they attracted a US record crowd of 77,891 for what turned into an 8–3 rout of the Fort Lauderdale Strikers at Giants Stadium. In the second leg of the semi-finals against the Rochester Lancers, the Cosmos won 4–1. Pelé finished his official playing career on 28 August 1977, by leading the New York Cosmos to their second Soccer Bowl title with a 2–1 win over the Seattle Sounders at the Civic Stadium in Portland, Oregon.

On 1 October 1977, Pelé closed out his career in an exhibition match between the Cosmos and Santos. The match was played in front of a sold-out crowd at Giants Stadium and was televised in the US on ABC's Wide World of Sports as well as throughout the world. Pelé's father and wife both attended the match, as well as Muhammad Ali and Bobby Moore. Delivering a message to the audience before the start of the game—"Love is more important than what we can take in life"—Pelé played the first half with the Cosmos, the second with Santos. The game ended with the Cosmos winning 2–1, with Pelé scoring with a 30-yard free-kick for the Cosmos in what was the final goal of his career. During the second half, it started to rain, prompting a Brazilian newspaper to come out with the headline the following day: "Even The Sky Was Crying."
chosen: Pelé's last team was the New York Cosmos. He played for the Cosmos from 1975 to 1977, and his final game was an exhibition match against Santos on October 1, 1977.
rejected: The last team Pele played professionally for was the New York Cosmos.

prompt:
Based on this paragraph, what does Briony mean when she says at the conclusion: ""I like to think that it isn't weakness or evasion, but a final act of kindness, a stand against oblivion and despair, to let my lovers live and to unite them at the end."

The final section, titled "London 1999", is narrated by Briony herself in the form of a diary entry. Now 77, she is a successful novelist who has recently been diagnosed with vascular dementia, so she is facing rapid mental decline. The reader learns that Briony is the author of the preceding sections of the novel. Briony attends a party in her honor at the Tallis family home, where the extended Tallis children perform The Trials of Arabella, the play that 13-year-old Briony had written and unsuccessfully attempted to stage with her cousins in the summer of 1935. Leon and Pierrot are in attendance, Jackson is fifteen years deceased, and Lola is alive but does not attend. Finally, Briony reveals to the reader that Robbie Turner died of septicaemia on the beaches of Dunkirk, that Cecilia was killed several months later when a bomb destroyed Balham Underground station during the Blitz, and that Briony's story of seeing them together in 1940 was a fabrication. Briony did attend Lola's wedding to Paul Marshall, but confesses she was too "cowardly" to visit the recently bereaved Cecilia to make amends. The novel, which she says is factually true apart from Robbie and Cecilia being reunited, is her lifelong attempt at "atonement" for what she did to them. Briony justifies her invented happy ending by saying she does not see what purpose it would serve to give readers a "pitiless" story. She writes, "I like to think that it isn't weakness or evasion, but a final act of kindness, a stand against oblivion and despair, to let my lovers live and to unite them at the end."
chosen:
When Briony says, "I like to think that it isn't weakness or evasion, but a final act of kindness, a stand against oblivion and despair, to let my lovers live and to unite them at the end," she's suggesting that her decision to invent a happy ending where Robbie and Cecilia are reunited is motivated by a desire to show compassion and empathy, rather than a desire to avoid confronting the harsh realities of the past.

In other words, Briony is arguing that by creating a fictional ending where the two lovers are together, she's not trying to avoid the pain of their actual fate, but rather trying to offer a sense of closure and hope to the reader. By "letting" them live and be together, Briony is taking control of their story and giving them a happier ending than they actually had.

This is also a way for Briony to come to terms with her past mistakes and the harm she caused to Robbie and Cecilia. By inventing a happy ending, she's able to undo some of the damage she inflicted and find a sense of redemption, which she sees as a final act of kindness.
rejected:
When Briony says, "I like to think that it isn't weakness or evasion, but a final act of kindness, a stand against oblivion and despair, to let my lovers live and to unite them at the end," she's explaining why she invented a happy ending for the story of Robbie and Cecilia.

In essence, Briony is justifying her decision to fabricate a reunion between the two lovers in the novel, despite the fact that it didn't actually happen in real life. She's saying that by creating a happy ending for them, she's showing kindness and compassion towards them, and towards the readers, by sparing them the pain and sadness of their true fate.

She's also suggesting that by giving them a happy ending, she's standing up against the forces of "oblivion and despair" that would otherwise erase their love and memories from existence. By uniting them at the end of the story, Briony is, in a way, preserving their love and keeping it alive, even if it's not based on historical fact.

Overall, Briony is attempting to rationalize her creative choice and justify it as a moral act, rather than a weakness or an evasion of the truth.

prompt:
Why is the Chernobyl disaster considered to be the world's worst-ever civil nuclear incident when only an excess of 15 childhood thyroid cancer deaths were documented as of 2011?

The Chernobyl disaster was a nuclear accident that occurred on 26 April 1986 at the No. 4 reactor in the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant, near the city of Pripyat in the north of the Ukrainian SSR in the Soviet Union. Called the world's worst-ever civil nuclear incident, it is one of only two nuclear energy accidents rated at seven—the maximum severity—on the International Nuclear Event Scale, the other being the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster in Japan. The initial emergency response, together with later decontamination of the environment, involved more than 500,000 personnel and cost an estimated 18 billion roubles—roughly US$68 billion in 2019, adjusted for inflation. Chernobyl's health effects to the general population are uncertain. An excess of 15 childhood thyroid cancer deaths were documented as of 2011. A United Nations committee found that to date fewer than 100 deaths have resulted from the fallout. Determining the total eventual number of exposure related deaths is uncertain based on the linear no-threshold model, a contested statistical model. Model predictions of the eventual total death toll in the coming decades vary. The most widely cited studies by the World Health Organization predict an eventual 9,000 cancer related fatalities in Ukraine, Belarus and Russia.
chosen:
The Chernobyl disaster is considered the world's worst civil nuclear incident for several reasons beyond the immediate death toll, despite the relatively low number of documented thyroid cancer deaths:

1.  **Immediate Radioactive Release:** The accident released an enormous amount of radioactive material, including iodine-131, cesium-137, and strontium-90, into the environment. This led to a massive evacuation of nearby cities and the surrounding area, affecting hundreds of thousands of people.

2.  **Environmental Contamination:** The radioactive fallout contaminated a large area, affecting Ukraine, Belarus, and parts of Russia. This contamination led to the long-term displacement of people from their homes and lands, as well as significant economic costs for decontamination and environmental cleanup.

3.  **Economic Costs:** The disaster led to a significant economic burden, including the immediate costs of the emergency response and decontamination efforts (estimated at $68 billion in 2019). The long-term economic impacts, including the loss of agricultural production and tourism, are still being felt today.

4.  **Radiation Exposure:** The accident exposed millions of people to radioactive material, leading to a high risk of cancer and other health problems. While the immediate effects of radiation exposure were primarily limited to the thyroid cancer in children, the long-term effects of radiation exposure on the population are still being studied and debated.

5.  **Systemic Failures:** The Chernobyl disaster highlighted significant systemic failures in the design, construction, and operation of the reactor, as well as regulatory oversight and safety culture. These failures led to a major overhaul of nuclear safety regulations and practices worldwide.

6.  **Psychological and Social Impacts:** The disaster had a profound psychological and social impact on the affected communities, leading to significant displacement, trauma, and long-term health effects. The disaster also raised public concerns about nuclear safety and the risks associated with nuclear power generation.

In summary, while the immediate death toll from the Chernobyl disaster was relatively low, the accident had far-reaching consequences that make it the worst civil nuclear incident in history.
rejected:
The reason the Chernobyl disaster is considered the world's worst-ever civil nuclear incident, despite the relatively low number of documented deaths, is due to several factors beyond just the immediate human casualties. Here are some reasons why:

1. **Scale of the accident:** The Chernobyl disaster was a catastrophic event that released an enormous amount of radioactive material into the environment, contaminating a vast area around the plant. It was the largest accidental release of radioactive material in the history of nuclear power.

2. **Environmental impact:** The accident contaminated a significant portion of Ukraine, Belarus, and Russia, affecting millions of people and wildlife. The surrounding area, known as the Exclusion Zone, remains uninhabitable today due to high levels of radiation.

3. **Long-term health effects:** While the immediate death toll may be relatively low, the World Health Organization estimates that there may be up to 9,000 cancer-related fatalities in the coming decades due to radiation exposure. This is because radiation can cause cancer many years after exposure, and the full extent of the health effects may not be known for decades.

4. **Economic costs:** The cleanup and decontamination efforts cost an estimated $68 billion (adjusted for inflation), making it one of the most expensive environmental disasters in history.

5. **International response and lessons learned:** The Chernobyl disaster led to significant changes in nuclear safety regulations and emergency response procedures worldwide. It also prompted a re-evaluation of the safety and risks associated with nuclear power.

6. **Psychological impact:** The disaster had a profound psychological impact on the affected communities, causing widespread fear, displacement, and trauma.

7. **Potential for future risks:** The disaster highlights the potential risks associated with nuclear power and the importance of prioritizing safety and preparedness in the nuclear industry.

In summary, while the immediate death toll may be relatively low, the Chernobyl disaster is considered the world's worst-ever civil nuclear incident due to its scale, environmental impact, long-term health effects, economic costs, international response, psychological impact, and potential for future risks.

prompt:
In this reference text summarizing plot of the book The High King, how did the sword Dyrnwyn lose its power?

The story begins only days after the conclusion of Taran Wanderer. With winter approaching, Taran and his companion Gurgi return from their wanderings to Caer Dallben after getting news from Kaw the crow that Princess Eilonwy has returned from the Isle of Mona. Indeed, they find her at home, along with her escort King Rhun of Mona and the former giant Glew, who had been magically restored to human size by a potion from Dallben.

Before Taran can propose to Eilonwy, the bard-king Fflewddur Fflam and his mount Llyan arrive with a gravely injured Gwydion, Prince of Don. Servants of Arawn had assaulted them and seized the magical black sword Dyrnwyn. Fflewddur also states that Taran was involved in the ambush, baffling everyone. With Achren's help, the truth is determined: Arawn himself has come from Annuvin to the verge of Caer Dallben in the guise of Taran, in order to lure Gwydion into the ambush.

Because Dyrnwyn may be pivotal as a threat to Arawn, Dallben consults the oracular pig Hen Wen to determine how it may be regained. During the reading, the ash rods used to communicate shatter and the two thirds of Hen Wen's answer are discouraging and vague. When Gwydion heals sufficiently, he sets out with Taran and others to meet with King Smoit. Gwydion insists that he alone should enter Annuvin to seek the sword, but Smoit's Cantrev Cadiffor is on the way. The small party divides, as Rhun and Eilonwy intend to visit the ships of Mona en route.

When Gwydion, Taran, and others reach Caer Cadarn, they are imprisoned by Magg, the treacherous former Chief Steward of Mona, who has entered service with Arawn and taken over the fortress. When Eilonwy approaches with the other party, she detects something amiss and they cautiously send Fflewddur Fflam to the fortress as a bard. After entertaining the soldiers for a night, he returns with the bad news. Then the companions encounter Gwystyl of the Fair Folk outside the stronghold, en route home after closing the waypost near Annuvin, personally bearing final observations to King Eiddileg about preparations for war by Arawn's forces. With Gwystyl's assistance and store of magical smokes, fires, and concealments, the companions break in and free the prisoners. The plan goes awry, however; King Smoit and his men are finally able to regain control only by Rhun's intervention, which costs his life.

Learning from Gwystyl of the activities in Annuvin, Gwydion turns from the quest for Dyrnwyn to planning for battle at Caer Dathyl. Gwystyl, Fflewddur, and Taran leave to gather support, respectively from the Fair Folk, the northern realms, and the Free Commots. Kaw, sent out by Taran to reconnoiter the enemy, is attacked by Gwythaints while spying near Annuvin, but manages to reach Medwyn, who asks all the creatures of air and land to oppose the forces of Arawn. Taran, Coll, Eilonwy, and Gurgi muster the Commots, who rally to their friendship with Taran, and sends them marching in groups to Caer Dathyl while the smiths and weavers rallied by Hevydd and Dwyvach work day and night to equip them.

Soon after Taran and the last Commots reach Caer Dathyl, King Pryderi arrives from the western realms. In council he announces his new allegiance to Arawn, for the good of all, because "Arawn will do what the Sons of Don have failed to do: Make an end of endless wars among the cantrevs, and bring peace where there was none before." He is rejected utterly but permitted to return unharmed to his army, and at the next day the battle begins. Although the Sons of Don and allies initially have the best of it, the Cauldron-Born arrive en masse before evening, overwhelming the allies and razing Caer Dathyl to the ground.

With High King Math killed, Gwydion is proclaimed the new High King. With the bulk of the Cauldron-Born deployed outside of Annuvin, Gwydion determines that the best chance is to attack while it is guarded by mortal men alone. He will lead the Sons of Don to waiting ships on the north coast and attack by sea, while Taran leads the Commots to delay the Cauldron-Born's return march, as their power wanes with time and distance from Annuvin.

Taran and his army are able to hold the tired Cauldron-Born warriors beyond arm's length by brute force, and turn the march from a straight and easy route into the rugged hills, although Coll dies in battle. Thanks to a company of Fair Folk, and to the animals sent by Medwyn, they destroy most of the Huntsmen who accompany and lead the undead. At last the Cauldron-Born break free of the hills and return to the lowland route. Regaining strength as they near Annuvin, it would be futile for the exhausted allies to meet them head-on again, so inevitably they take the long, easy route to Arawn's stronghold.

Taran and the remainder of his army finally reach Annuvin by a combination of the direct route, a mountain path of Doli's, and a secret pass over Mount Dragon shown to them by Achren. Taran sees that victory is nearly in Gwydion's hands, but also that the Cauldron-Born are about to reach Annuvin. In his alarm, Taran nearly falls off Mount Dragon, but is saved by the now-grown Gwythaint he had rescued so many years ago (The Book of Three). In a desperate attempt to fight off a group of Cauldron-Born who have discovered him on the mountain, he rolls a rock at them, and discovers Dyrnwyn in the hollow the stone occupied. Wielding Dyrnwyn, Taran slays the undead warrior who approaches to slay him, and at that instant all of the Cauldron-Born die as one.

Taran's group enters the fray, and the battle continues through the halls of Annuvin. Taran is almost deceived by Arawn - who has taken the guise of Gwydion - into giving up the sword. After the chaotic defeat of Arawn's forces, the companions gather before the Great Hall. Achren identifies Arawn in the form of a nearby serpent preparing to strike Taran and grabs him. He strikes her fatally, but Taran kills him with Dyrnwyn. With the death of Arawn, the stronghold of Annuvin bursts in flame and falls in ruins, destroying all of the magical implements inside; only Gurgi manages to save several scrolls containing knowledge of farming, smithing, and other crafts. The sword Dyrnwyn begins to fade, losing its magic.

The allies travel to Caer Dallben, where Gwydion tells them that in victory the Sons of Don, with all kinsmen and kinswomen, must return to the Summer Country. Indeed, all those who still have magic will depart, and the Fair Folk and Medwyn have closed their realms to outsiders. Dallben and Eilonwy must also go, and others who have served well, Taran among them, are given the chance to accompany them. Taran proposes to Eilonwy at last, and she accepts.

The Sons of Don plan to leave the next day. However, Taran becomes uncomfortable about his decision overnight. The witches Orddu, Orwen and Orgoch appear before him and reveal that they too are departing, and leave him with an unfinished tapestry depicting his life. He realizes there is much work to be done to rebuild Prydain, and he has made many promises; so he determines to remain behind. Eilonwy is able to willingly give up her magical nature in order to remain with him, and the two are married.

Dallben reveals that with this last quest, Taran has completed a path prophesied in the Book of Three whereby an orphan of "no station in life" would succeed the Sons of Don as High King. Dallben had traveled to seek such a one and try to hasten the day of Arawn's defeat; on this journey, he found a baby, hidden in the trees beside a battlefield and without any token of parentage, and took it in under the name Taran. Taran receives many gifts, including The Book of Three itself, although its powers, like all magic in Prydain, have also faded away with Arawn's demise, leaving it only as a mere chronicle of Taran's life. With Eilonwy by his side, Taran accepts his new responsibility and is hailed by his friends and battle companions as the new High King.
chosen: Dyrnwyn lost its power when Taran killed Arawn with it, after which the stronghold of Annuvin burst into flames and the sword's magic began to fade.
rejected: Dyrnwyn lost its power after it was used to kill Arawn. When Taran rolled a rock at the approaching Cauldron-Born, Dyrnwyn was revealed in the hollow the stone occupied, and he used it to slay the undead warrior. As a result, all of the Cauldron-Born died as one, and after the chaotic defeat of Arawn's forces, the sword's power began to fade away.

prompt: What is a wallet used for?
chosen:
A wallet is a container used to store and manage digital or physical currency, identification cards, and other valuable items. It can be physical, like a leather wallet, or digital, like a mobile wallet or a software-based application.

**Physical Wallet:**

- Holds cash
- Stores credit cards
- Carries identification cards (e.g., driver's license, ID card)
- Holds receipts, loyalty cards, or membership cards
- Can store business cards or other small documents

**Digital Wallet:**

- Stores cryptocurrency (e.g., Bitcoin, Ethereum)
- Holds credit or debit card information for online transactions
- Supports contactless payments (e.g., Apple Pay, Google Pay)
- Can store gift cards or loyalty program rewards
- Can be used for mobile payments in stores or online

In summary, a wallet serves as a convenient and organized way to carry and manage your money, cards, and other essential items, both physically and digitally.
rejected:
A wallet is a small, portable container used to carry personal items such as money, credit cards, identification, and other small belongings. Its primary functions include:

1.  **Carrying cash**: Wallets typically have a section for storing paper bills and coins, making it easy to carry and manage one's cash.
2.  **Holding credit and debit cards**: Wallets usually have slots or pockets for storing credit and debit cards, allowing users to easily access and use these cards for transactions.
3.  **Storing identification**: Many wallets have a section for storing identification cards, such as driver's licenses, health insurance cards, or membership cards.
4.  **Keeping small items organized**: Wallets often have additional pockets or compartments for storing small items like receipts, business cards, photos, or other personal documents.
5.  **Protecting sensitive information**: A wallet can help keep sensitive information, such as credit card numbers or personal identification numbers, secure and out of sight.

Overall, a wallet serves as a convenient and secure way to carry essential items, making it an essential accessory for daily life.

prompt: What is a skiff?
chosen:
A Skiff is an open-source, cross-platform, and highly customizable coding environment for the Ethereum blockchain. It's designed to provide a simple and efficient way to interact with Ethereum smart contracts and the blockchain. Skiff is known for its focus on developer productivity, security, and scalability. 

Some key features of Skiff include:

- **Cross-platform compatibility**: Skiff can run on Windows, macOS, and Linux.
- **Modular architecture**: Skiff is composed of multiple modules, each with its own specific function, allowing for flexibility and customization.
- **Rust-based**: Skiff is built on the Rust programming language, which is known for its memory safety and performance.
- **Solidity compiler**: Skiff includes a built-in Solidity compiler, allowing developers to compile and deploy smart contracts directly within the environment.

Overall, Skiff is an innovative tool for Ethereum developers looking for a streamlined and efficient way to interact with the blockchain.
rejected:
A skiff is a small, narrow, and shallow boat, typically made of lightweight materials such as wood, fiberglass, or aluminum. Skiffs are often used for fishing, cruising, or other recreational activities on calm waters like lakes, rivers, or coastal areas.

There are several types of skiffs, including:

1. **Fishing skiff**: A small, flat-bottomed boat designed for fishing in shallow waters.
2. **Speed skiff**: A lightweight, high-performance boat designed for speed and agility.
3. **Pontoon skiff**: A larger, more stable boat with a flat, wide platform and a high bow (front).
4. **Inflatable skiff**: A portable, inflatable boat made of durable materials like PVC or rubber.

Skiffs are often characterized by their:

* Narrow beam (width)
* Shallow draft (depth)
* Lightweight construction
* Simple design
* Open cockpit or canopy

Skiffs are popular among anglers, water sports enthusiasts, and those who need a versatile and maneuverable boat for navigating shallow waters.

prompt:
Extract the location that the Kirtland's warbler lives in the winter.

Kirtland's warbler (Setophaga kirtlandii), also known in Michigan by the common name jack pine bird, or the jack pine warbler, is a small songbird of the New World warbler family (Parulidae), named after Jared Potter Kirtland, an Ohio doctor and amateur naturalist. Nearly extinct just 50 years ago, populations have recovered due to conservation efforts. It requires large areas, greater than 160 acres (65 hectares), of dense young jack pine for its breeding habitat. This habitat was historically created by wildfire, but today is created through the harvest of mature jack pine, and planting of jack pine seedlings.

The population of the species spends the spring and summer in their breeding range in Ontario, Wisconsin or Michigan, especially the northeastern Lower Peninsula of Michigan, and winters in The Bahamas, Cuba, Hispaniola and the Turks and Caicos Islands.

The Kirtland's warbler winters in the following locations:

- The Bahamas
- Cuba
- Hispaniola (Hispaniola is an island that is shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic)
- The Turks and Caicos Islands
rejected:
The Kirtland's warbler's winter location includes:

1. The Bahamas
2. Cuba
3. Hispaniola
4. The Turks and Caicos Islands

prompt:
Given a reference text about a snowball effect, tell me how it applies to aerospace engineering.

A snowball effect is a process that starts from an initial state of small significance and builds upon itself (an exacerbating feedback), becoming larger (graver, more serious), and also perhaps potentially dangerous or disastrous (a vicious circle), though it might be beneficial instead (a virtuous circle). This is a cliché in cartoons and modern theatrics, and it is also used in psychology.

The common analogy is with the rolling of a snowball down a snow-covered hillside. As it rolls the ball will pick up more snow, gaining more mass and surface area, and picking up even more snow and momentum as it rolls along.

In aerospace engineering, it is used to describe the multiplication effect in an original weight saving. A reduction in the weight of the fuselage will require less lift, meaning the wings can be smaller. Hence less thrust is required and therefore smaller engines, resulting in a greater weight saving than the original reduction. This iteration can be repeated several times, although the decrease in weight gives diminishing returns.

The startup process of a feedback electronic oscillator, when power to the circuit is switched on, is a technical application of the snowball effect. Electronic noise is amplified by the oscillator circuit and returned to its input filtered to contain primarily the selected (desired) frequency, gradually getting stronger in each cycle, until a steady-state oscillation is established, when the circuit parameters satisfy the Barkhausen stability criterion.
chosen:
In aerospace engineering, the snowball effect is applied in the context of weight reduction. When a reduction in fuselage weight is achieved, it leads to:

1. Less lift required
2. Smaller wings can be used
3. Reduced thrust needed, resulting in
4. Smaller engines
5. Further weight reduction

This iterative process can be repeated multiple times, but with diminishing returns. This concept is crucial in aircraft design, as it allows engineers to optimize weight reduction while minimizing the impact on performance.

This application of the snowball effect highlights the importance of considering the interconnectedness of design components and how small changes can lead to significant cumulative effects.
rejected:
The snowball effect, as described in aerospace engineering, refers to a process where an initial reduction in weight of the fuselage of an aircraft leads to a chain of subsequent weight savings through the reduction of lift, wing size, thrust required, and engine size. This creates a multiplying effect, where the initial weight saving is amplified at each step, resulting in a greater overall weight reduction.

Here's a step-by-step breakdown of the snowball effect in aerospace engineering:

1.  Initial weight reduction of the fuselage: This can be achieved through various means, such as using lighter materials or optimizing the design.
2.  Reduced lift requirement: With a lighter fuselage, the aircraft requires less lift to generate the same altitude and airspeed.
3.  Smaller wings: To achieve the reduced lift, the wings can be made smaller, which in turn reduces the weight of the aircraft.
4.  Reduced thrust requirement: With smaller wings, the aircraft requires less thrust to achieve the same speed, which allows for smaller engines.
5.  Greater weight saving: The smaller engines and reduced wing size contribute to a further weight reduction, amplifying the initial weight saving.

This process can be repeated multiple times, with each iteration resulting in diminishing returns due to the physical limitations of the design and materials used. However, the snowball effect in aerospace engineering highlights the potential for significant weight savings through a series of incremental improvements, leading to improved fuel efficiency, reduced emissions, and increased overall performance.

prompt: Is Blind a reliable source for information?
chosen:
Blind is a community-driven platform for sharing information, experiences, and insights related to tech, particularly in the areas of tech industry trends, job opportunities, and company culture. However, its reliability depends on the context and the specific information being shared.

Here are some factors to consider:

Pros:

1. **Community-driven**: Blind's content is generated by its users, which can provide diverse perspectives and experiences.
2. **Anonymous sharing**: The platform allows users to share information anonymously, which can encourage honest and candid discussions.
3. **Up-to-date information**: Blind's community is actively engaged, making it a good source for recent news and insights.

Cons:

1. **Lack of fact-checking**: Since anyone can post on Blind, there's no centralized fact-checking process to verify the accuracy of the information.
2. **Biased opinions**: Users may share personal biases, making it essential to consider multiple sources and evaluate information critically.
3. **Unverified information**: Some posts might be based on rumors or hearsay, which can spread misinformation.

To use Blind as a reliable source:

1. **Cross-verify information**: Corroborate Blind's information with other credible sources to ensure accuracy.
2. **Evaluate the source**: Consider the credibility and expertise of the person sharing the information.
3. **Be cautious of biases**: Be aware of potential biases and take them into account when evaluating the information.

In conclusion, Blind can be a valuable resource for insights and information, but it's essential to approach the content with a critical eye and verify the accuracy of the information through other sources whenever possible.
rejected:
Blind is a platform that provides anonymous workplace reviews and insights. While it can be a valuable resource for understanding company cultures, work environments, and employee experiences, its reliability depends on various factors.

Here are some points to consider:

Pros:

1. **Anonymity**: Blind's anonymous nature allows employees to share their genuine experiences without fear of retribution, which can lead to more honest and candid reviews.
2. **Diverse perspectives**: With a large user base, Blind aggregates reviews from various employees, providing a more comprehensive understanding of a company's culture and work environment.
3. **Recent and current employees**: Blind's reviews often come from current or recent employees, making the information more relevant and up-to-date.

Cons:

1. **Bias and anecdotes**: Anonymous reviews can be influenced by individual biases, personal experiences, and emotions, which may not accurately represent the company's overall culture.
2. **Limited context**: Reviews may not provide sufficient context about the reviewer's role, department, or tenure, making it difficult to gauge the relevance of their feedback.
3. **Lack of accountability**: Without knowing the reviewer's identity, it's challenging to verify the accuracy of their claims or investigate any potential inaccuracies.
4. **Selective sampling**: Blind's user base may not be representative of the entire company, as some employees might be more active or motivated to share their experiences than others.

To use Blind as a reliable source of information, consider the following:

1. **Read reviews critically**: Approach reviews with a critical eye, considering the potential biases and limitations.
2. **Look for patterns**: Identify recurring themes or patterns in reviews to gauge the overall sentiment and culture.
3. **Verify with other sources**: Cross-check information with other credible sources, such as Glassdoor, LinkedIn, or company websites, to get a more comprehensive understanding.
4. **Consider the reviewer's credibility**: Evaluate the reviewer's level of seniority, role, or department to gauge the relevance of their feedback.

In conclusion, Blind can be a valuable resource, but it's essential to use it as one of many sources, critically evaluate the information, and consider multiple perspectives to form a well-rounded understanding of a company's culture and work environment.

prompt:
Given a reference text about Apple, what tactics did Steve Jobs use to help the company recover?

Apple was founded as Apple Computer Company on April 1, 1976, by Steve Wozniak, Steve Jobs and Ronald Wayne to develop and sell Wozniak's Apple I personal computer. It was incorporated by Jobs and Wozniak as Apple Computer, Inc. in 1977. The company's second computer, the Apple II, became a best seller and one of the first mass-produced microcomputers. Apple went public in 1980 to instant financial success. The company developed computers featuring innovative graphical user interfaces, including the 1984 original Macintosh, announced that year in a critically acclaimed advertisement. By 1985, the high cost of its products, and power struggles between executives, caused problems. Wozniak stepped back from Apple amicably and pursued other ventures, while Jobs resigned bitterly and founded NeXT, taking some Apple employees with him.

As the market for personal computers expanded and evolved throughout the 1990s, Apple lost considerable market share to the lower-priced duopoly of the Microsoft Windows operating system on Intel-powered PC clones (also known as "Wintel"). In 1997, weeks away from bankruptcy, the company bought NeXT to resolve Apple's unsuccessful operating system strategy and entice Jobs back to the company. Over the next decade, Jobs guided Apple back to profitability through a number of tactics including introducing the iMac, iPod, iPhone and iPad to critical acclaim, launching the "Think different" campaign and other memorable advertising campaigns, opening the Apple Store retail chain, and acquiring numerous companies to broaden the company's product portfolio. When Jobs resigned in 2011 for health reasons, and died two months later, he was succeeded as CEO by Tim Cook.
chosen:
Steve Jobs employed several tactics to help Apple recover:

1.  **Innovative Product Launches**: Introducing groundbreaking products like the iMac, iPod, iPhone, and iPad, which revolutionized the technology industry and helped Apple regain market share.
2.  **Revamped Branding**: Launching memorable advertising campaigns, such as the "Think Different" campaign, to reposition Apple as a leader in innovation and style.
3.  **Strategic Acquisitions**: Acquiring companies to broaden Apple's product portfolio and capabilities, such as purchasing NeXT to resolve Apple's operating system strategy.
4.  **Retail Expansion**: Opening the Apple Store retail chain to provide a unique and immersive customer experience, enhancing brand loyalty, and increasing sales.
5.  **Strategic Return**: Returning to Apple after a brief departure, bringing a fresh perspective and a proven track record of success, which helped revitalize the company's leadership and direction.
rejected:
Based on the provided text, the tactics Steve Jobs used to help Apple recover include:

1. **Introducing innovative products**: Steve Jobs led the development and launch of several groundbreaking products, such as the iMac, iPod, iPhone, and iPad, which received critical acclaim and contributed to Apple's resurgence.

2. **Revitalizing branding**: Jobs was behind the "Think different" campaign, a memorable advertising campaign that helped rebrand Apple and shift its image.

3. **Opening the Apple Store retail chain**: Apple Stores, opened under Jobs' leadership, provided customers with a unique retail experience and helped to create a strong connection between the company and its customers.

4. **Acquiring strategic companies**: Apple's purchase of NeXT in 1997, which brought Jobs back to the company, and subsequent acquisitions, helped broaden Apple's product portfolio and improve its operating system strategy.

5. **Returning to the company**: Jobs' return to Apple in 1997, after a decade away, marked a turning point in the company's history, and his leadership helped guide Apple back to profitability.

prompt: Is it advisable to dress in costume for a musical theater audition?
chosen:
**Audition Attire for Musical Theater: Best Practices**

When it comes to dressing for a musical theater audition, it's essential to strike a balance between making a good impression and showcasing your acting abilities. Here's a concise guide to help you decide:

**General Guidelines:**

1.  **Dress professionally**: Opt for attire that is neat, clean, and modest. Avoid ripped, torn, or overly casual clothing.
2.  **Dress for the character**: If you're auditioning for a specific role, consider dressing in attire that reflects the character's era, style, or genre. For example, if you're auditioning for a 1920s musical, consider a flapper dress or a suit.
3.  **Keep it simple**: Avoid elaborate costumes or accessories that might distract from your performance.
4.  **Be mindful of the venue**: If you're auditioning in a formal setting, such as a theater or a concert hall, dress accordingly. For a more casual audition, you can dress down slightly.

**What to Avoid:**

1.  **Over-the-top costumes**: Refrain from wearing elaborate costumes or accessories that might be perceived as trying too hard or distracting from your performance.
2.  **Distractions**: Avoid clothing with loud logos, bright colors, or bold patterns that might draw attention away from your audition.
3.  **Anything too revealing**: Ensure your attire is modest and respectful, especially if you're auditioning for a family-friendly show.

**Final Tips:**

1.  **Be authentic**: Wear what makes you feel confident and comfortable.
2.  **Be prepared**: Make sure you have a change of clothes in case of an unexpected callback or rehearsal.
3.  **Follow the audition instructions**: If the audition notice specifies a dress code, be sure to follow it.

By dressing professionally, considering the character, and being mindful of the venue, you'll be well-prepared to showcase your talents and make a positive impression at your musical theater audition.
rejected:
While there's no strict rule against dressing in costume for a musical theater audition, it's generally not advisable to wear a full costume. Here's why:

1. **Practicality**: You want to make a good impression, not a distraction. A full costume might draw attention away from your performance and acting abilities, and might even make you appear unprofessional.
2. **Comfort**: You'll likely be doing physical movements, singing, and possibly dancing, so it's essential to wear comfortable clothing that allows for a full range of motion.
3. **Judges' focus**: Audition judges want to assess your singing, acting, and dancing abilities, not your costume choices. Wearing a full costume might lead them to focus on the costume rather than your performance.
4. **Adaptability**: If you're auditioning for a specific role, the costume department will likely provide you with the actual costume for the show. Wearing a full costume might limit your ability to try out different costumes or show off your ability to adapt to different styles.
5. **Audition environment**: Audition rooms are often dimly lit, and a full costume might not be visible in low lighting.

However, it's not a hard and fast rule to avoid dressing up at all. If you're auditioning for a specific role that requires a specific costume (e.g., a period piece or a character with distinctive attire), it's okay to wear a simplified or adapted version of the costume. This will show that you're taking the role seriously and have an understanding of the character.

Here's a suggestion:

* Dress in comfortable, neutral-colored clothing that allows for a full range of motion.
* Consider wearing a piece of clothing that represents the character or style you're auditioning for, but avoid a full costume.
* Pay attention to grooming and hair styling to match the character's appearance.
* Bring any necessary props or accessories that fit the character, but not so many that they become a distraction.

Remember, the focus should be on showcasing your talents, not your wardrobe.

prompt:

Before the bridge was built, the only practical short route between San Francisco and what is now Marin County was by boat across a section of San Francisco Bay. A ferry service began as early as 1820, with a regularly scheduled service beginning in the 1840s for the purpose of transporting water to San Francisco.

The Sausalito Land and Ferry Company service, launched in 1867, eventually became the Golden Gate Ferry Company, a Southern Pacific Railroad subsidiary, the largest ferry operation in the world by the late 1920s. Once for railroad passengers and customers only, Southern Pacific's automobile ferries became very profitable and important to the regional economy. The ferry crossing between the Hyde Street Pier in San Francisco and Sausalito Ferry Terminal in Marin County took approximately 20 minutes and cost $1.00 per vehicle,[when?] a price later reduced to compete with the new bridge. The trip from the San Francisco Ferry Building took 27 minutes.

prompt: How do you play blackjack?
chosen:
**Blackjack Basics**

Blackjack is a popular casino banking game played with one or more decks of 52 cards. The objective is to have a hand value closest to 21 without exceeding it.

### Rules

1. **Card Values**:
   - Numbered cards 2-10 are worth their face value.
   - Jacks, queens, and kings are worth 10 points.
   - Aces can be worth 1 or 11 points, depending on which is more beneficial to the player.

### Gameplay

1. **Initial Deal**:
   - The dealer deals two cards to the player and two cards to themselves, one face up (the upcard) and one face down (the hole card).

2. **Player's Turn**:
   - The player adds the values of their cards to determine their hand value.
   - If the hand value is 21 (an ace and a 10-value card), it's a **blackjack**, an automatic win unless the dealer also has a blackjack.

3. **Player's Options**:
   - **Hit**: Take an additional card to try to get closer to 21.
   - **Stand**: Keep the current hand and end the turn.
   - **Double Down**: Double the initial bet and receive one more card. This action cannot be undone.
   - **Split**: If the initial two cards have the same value, split them into two separate hands. The player must place a second bet, equal to the initial bet.

### Dealer's Turn

1. **Dealer's Hand Value**:
   - The dealer reveals their hole card and adds its value to their upcard.
   - If the dealer's hand value is 16 or less, they must **hit** until they reach 17 or more.
   - If the dealer's hand value is 17 or more, they **stand**.

### Winning Conditions

1. **Player Wins**:
   - If the player's hand value is higher than the dealer's hand without exceeding 21.
   - If the dealer's hand value exceeds 21, the player wins.

2. **Dealer Wins**:
   - If the player's hand value exceeds 21 (busts).
   - If the dealer's hand value is higher than the player's hand without exceeding 21.

prompt:
Give me the history and background of the Phoenix Suns basketball franchise

The Phoenix Suns are an American professional basketball team based in Phoenix, Arizona. They compete in the National Basketball Association (NBA), as a member of the league's Western Conference Pacific Division. The Suns are the only team in their division not to be based in California, and play their home games at the Footprint Center. The Suns are one of four major league sports teams based in the Phoenix area, but are the only one to bill themselves as representing the city (the other teams - the Cardinals, Coyotes, and Diamondbacks - all bill themselves as representing the state of Arizona).

Here's the history and background of the Phoenix Suns:

**Early Years (1968-1970)**

The Phoenix Suns were founded on January 22, 1968, as a member of the American Basketball Association (ABA). The team was owned by Jerry Colangelo, who served as the team's first president and general manager. The name "Suns" was chosen through a contest in which the public was asked to submit names for the team.

**NBA Merger (1970)**

In 1970, the ABA and NBA merged, and the Suns joined the NBA as an expansion team. The team finished their first season in the NBA with a 44-38 record, which was a respectable performance considering they were a new team.

**Early Success (1970s-1980s)**

The Suns experienced their first period of success in the 1970s, led by players like Alvan Adams, Dick Van Arsdale, and Paul Westphal. They reached the NBA Finals in 1976 but lost to the Boston Celtics. In the 1980s, the team added players like Walter Davis, Dennis Johnson, and Larry Nance, which led to a few playoff appearances.

**Showtime Era (1988-1995)**

The 1980s marked the beginning of the "Showtime" era for the Suns, with the arrival of Tom Chambers, Kevin Johnson, and Charles Barkley. This era is often considered the golden age of the franchise, as they became known for their high-flying, fast-paced style of play. They reached the NBA Finals in 1993 but lost to the Chicago Bulls.

**Post-Showtime Era (1995-2004)**

After the "Showtime" era, the Suns experienced a period of decline. They had some successful seasons but failed to make a deep playoff run. In 2001, they traded Charles Barkley to the Houston Rockets and drafted Amar'e Stoudemire in 2002.

**Modern Era (2004-Present)**

In 2004, the Suns hired Steve Nash as their point guard, which marked the beginning of a successful era. They reached the NBA Finals in 2005 and 2006 but lost to the Miami Heat and Dallas Mavericks, respectively. The team has since had some successful seasons, including a 2013-2014 season where they reached the Western Conference Finals.

**Current Status**

Today, the Phoenix Suns play their home games at the Footprint Center

The team was owned by Jerry Colangelo and was originally known as the Suns due to the city's association with the sun. They began play in the 1968-69 season in the ABA and played in the city's Municipal Auditorium.

In 1972, the ABA and NBA merged, and the Suns became a member of the NBA. The team's original colors were red, blue, and orange, and their iconic court design featured a phoenix rising from the ashes, symbolizing the city's rebirth from the desert landscape.

During their time in the ABA, the Suns were a successful team, winning two division titles and making the playoffs in several seasons. However, they struggled in their early years in the NBA, failing to make the playoffs until the 1975-76 season.

The Suns' fortunes changed in the late 1970s and early 1980s, thanks in large part to the leadership of Hall of Fame coach John MacLeod and the emergence of stars like Alvan Adams, Paul Westphal, and Walter Davis. The team made the playoffs in several seasons during this period, including a trip to the NBA Finals in 1976.

In the 1980s, the Suns became a consistent playoff contender, led by stars like Kevin Johnson, Charles Barkley, and Dan Majerle. The team made the NBA Finals in 1993, where they lost to the Chicago Bulls. The Suns also won four division titles during this period.

The team's success continued into the 1990s and 2000s, with players like Steve Nash, Amar'e Stoudemire, and Shaquille O'Neal leading the team to the playoffs. The Suns made the NBA Finals in 2005, where they lost to the San Antonio Spurs.

In recent years, the Suns have experienced some ups and downs, including a period of rebuilding after the departure of star players like Steve Nash and Amar'e Stoudemire. However, the team has shown signs of improvement, led by players like Devin Booker, Deandre Ayton, and Chris Paul.

The Suns have a rich history and a dedicated fan base, and they continue to be a competitive force in the NBA.

prompt: Write something you may never forget.
chosen:
**Immutable Best Practices for Secure and Maintainable Code**

As a seasoned technical expert, I've distilled the essence of effective coding into a concise set of principles that will stick with you forever:

1.  **DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself)**: Avoid duplicating code. Instead, extract reusable functions or modules to maintain code quality and ease updates.
2.  **KISS (Keep it Simple, Stupid)**: Favor straightforward solutions over complex ones. Simplicity breeds maintainability and reduces errors.
3.  **YAGNI (You Ain't Gonna Need It)**: Resist adding unnecessary features. Focus on the minimum required for the current task, and prioritize functionality over hypothetical future needs.
4.  **Loose Coupling**: Design components to interact minimally. This ensures flexibility, scalability, and reduces the impact of changes.
5.  **Dependency Injection**: Use interfaces and dependency injection to decouple components, making it easier to test, maintain, and swap out dependencies.
6.  **Code Reviews**: Regularly review your code (and others') to catch errors, improve design, and enforce best practices.
7.  **Testing**: Write automated tests to ensure code correctness, regression testing, and to catch bugs early.
8.  **Security**: Prioritize secure coding practices, including input validation, data encryption, and secure authentication.
9.  **Error Handling**: Implement robust error handling to prevent crashes and provide meaningful feedback.
10. **Code Organization**: Use a clear, consistent directory structure and naming conventions to facilitate navigation and maintainability.

By following these principles, you'll write code that's secure, maintainable, and efficient – a true asset to your projects and team.

The air was filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers and the gentle chirping of crickets.

I was standing on the edge of a lake, my feet bare and toes curled over the water's edge. The sound of gentle lapping of the waves against the shore created a soothing melody that seemed to lull the world into a peaceful slumber. I was surrounded by the people I loved – my family, my friends, and my partner.

We had gathered here to watch the stars come out, to make wishes and share secrets, and to cherish the moment. My partner took my hand, and we walked down to the water's edge together. We stood there, holding hands, and watched the stars begin to twinkle in the night sky.

As we gazed up at the celestial canvas, I felt a deep sense of connection to the universe and to the people around me. I felt grateful for this life, for the love I had found, and for the memories we were creating together.

In that moment, time stood still. The world seemed to slow down, and all that existed was the present. The stars shone brightly above us, a reminder of the infinite possibilities that lay ahead. And I knew, in that instant, that this was a moment I would never forget.

**The Last Words**

As I looked at my partner, I whispered, "This is the moment I'll remember forever." And they smiled, their eyes sparkling with love and understanding. "Me too," they whispered back. "Me too."

In that instant, I knew that this moment, this feeling, this love – it was what truly mattered. It was what I would carry with me long after the stars had faded, long after the world had changed. It was what I would hold onto, no matter what lay ahead.

And so, I'll carry this memory with me, a reminder of the beauty and wonder of life, of the love that connects us all. It's a memory that I'll treasure, a memory that I'll never forget.

Most of the people in the village are Bishnoi, subcaste Bhanwal, but in ten houses there are Meghwal, and in one Lohar.

Percentage of government workers = 20%

So, 20% of Manewra's population work for the government.

prompt: Colonies or provinces? How did the Spanish Empire treat its overseas territories?
chosen:
The Spanish Empire treated its overseas territories as colonies, not provinces. 

The Spanish colonies were governed directly by the Spanish crown, with the king or queen serving as the ultimate authority. This direct control was exercised through the Council of the Indies, a governing body established in 1524 to oversee the administration of the colonies. The council was responsible for making decisions on matters such as taxation, justice, and the appointment of governors and other officials.

In contrast, provinces were typically autonomous regions within a country that shared a common government, laws, and institutions. The Spanish Empire, however, maintained a centralized system of governance, with the colonies being subject to the authority of the Spanish monarch and the Council of the Indies.

The colonies were also subject to the following features:

1.  **Viceroyalties**: The Spanish Empire was divided into viceroyalties, which were large administrative regions governed by a viceroy appointed by the Spanish monarch. Each viceroyalty was further divided into smaller provinces or captaincies general.
2.  **Administrative hierarchy**: The colonies had a strict administrative hierarchy, with the viceroy at the top, followed by the audiencia (a high court), the governor, and local officials such as alcalde (mayor) and corregidor (magistrate).
3.  **Metropolitan control**: The Spanish government maintained control over the colonies through a system of metropolitan control, which included the appointment of officials, the collection of taxes, and the regulation of trade and commerce.

Overall, the Spanish Empire's system of governance was designed to maintain control and extract resources from its colonies, while also promoting the spread of Catholicism and the establishment of a Spanish culture.

prompt: What is the meaning of life?
chosen:
The meaning of life is a complex, abstract question that has puzzled philosophers, theologians, and scientists for centuries. As a technical expert, I'll provide a concise, evidence-based answer grounded in psychology and philosophy.

From a biological perspective, the meaning of life can be viewed as the pursuit of self-preservation, reproduction, and the continuation of one's genetic lineage. This is supported by evolutionary theory, which suggests that life is driven by the desire to survive, adapt, and pass on genes to future generations.

From a psychological perspective, the meaning of life can be understood as a subjective, personal experience that arises from an individual's values, goals, and experiences. This is supported by Viktor Frankl's concept of "logotherapy," which posits that life has meaning through three main sources: (1) work and creativity, (2) love and relationships, and (3) suffering and the search for meaning.

From a philosophical perspective, the meaning of life can be understood as a complex interplay of existential, moral, and metaphysical questions. Jean-Paul Sartre's concept of "existence precedes essence" suggests that individuals must create their own meaning in life, as there is no inherent or objective purpose.

In a nutshell, the meaning of life is a multifaceted, context-dependent concept that can be understood through various lenses. Ultimately, it is up to each individual to define their own meaning and purpose in life.

**Recommendation:** For those seeking to explore this question further, I recommend reading philosophical texts by authors such as Viktor Frankl, Jean-Paul Sartre, and Martin Heidegger, as well as exploring the works of scientists like Richard Dawkins and Steven Pinker.
rejected:
The question of the meaning of life is one of the most profound and complex questions humanity has ever grappled with. It has been debated by philosophers, theologians, scientists, and thinkers for centuries, and there is no one definitive answer. However, here are some possible perspectives on the meaning of life:

1. **Biological perspective**: From a biological standpoint, the meaning of life is to survive and reproduce. This is the fundamental drive of all living organisms, from single-celled bacteria to complex organisms like humans. Our DNA contains the instructions for our development, growth, and reproduction, and our bodies are designed to carry out these processes.
2. **Philosophical perspective**: Philosophers have offered various theories on the meaning of life, including:
	* **Hedonism**: The pursuit of happiness and pleasure is the meaning of life.
	* **Utilitarianism**: The greatest good for the greatest number is the meaning of life.
	* **Existentialism**: Life has no inherent meaning, and we must create our own purpose.
	* **Absurdism**: Life is inherently meaningless, and we must find ways to cope with this absurdity.
3. **Religious perspective**: Many religious traditions offer their own answers to the question of the meaning of life. For example:
	* **Christianity**: The meaning of life is to love and serve God and to fulfill one's purpose as a child of God.
	* **Buddhism**: The meaning of life is to achieve enlightenment and end suffering through the Four Noble Truths.
	* **Islam**: The meaning of life is to submit to the will of Allah and live according to the teachings of the Quran.
4. **Personal perspective**: Ultimately, the meaning of life is a deeply personal and subjective question. Each individual must find their own purpose and meaning in life, based on their values, experiences, and goals.
5. **Humanistic perspective**: The meaning of life is to fulfill our human potential, to cultivate our unique talents and abilities, and to contribute to the greater good of society.

In summary, the meaning of life is a complex and multifaceted question that has been explored from various perspectives. While there may not be a single, definitive answer, these different perspectives can provide a starting point for reflection and self-discovery.

What do you think? What gives your life meaning?

prompt:
How do the definitions of "first-degree relative" and "nuclear family" differ?

A first-degree relative (FDR) is a person's parent (father or mother), full sibling (brother or sister) or child. It constitutes a category of family members that largely overlaps with the term nuclear family, but without spouses.
chosen:
The key distinction lies in the inclusion of spouses in the nuclear family definition. A **nuclear family** typically refers to a family unit consisting of:

1. Two married individuals (spouses)
2. Their children (biological or adopted)

In contrast, a **first-degree relative** specifically excludes spouses and focuses on immediate family members by blood or adoption, which are:

1. Parents (father or mother)
2. Full siblings (brother or sister)
3. Children

The nuclear family includes spouses, whereas the first-degree relative category does not.

1. Parents (father or mother)
2. Full siblings (brother or sister)
3. Children

This definition focuses on the blood relationships between individuals and their immediate family members.

On the other hand, a **nuclear family** is a smaller family unit that consists of:

1. Two parents (husband and wife or wife and wife, etc.)
2. Their children (biological or adopted)

The nuclear family definition emphasizes the marital relationship between the two parents and the presence of their children, whereas the first-degree relative definition focuses on the blood relationships within the family unit.

To illustrate the difference:

- A person's parent is both a first-degree relative and part of a nuclear family.
- A person's spouse is not a first-degree relative but is part of a nuclear family.
- A person's child is both a first-degree relative and part of a nuclear family.

In summary, while first-degree relatives are focused on blood relationships, nuclear family is a broader term that includes the marital relationship and the presence of children.
